newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Kinshasa residents react to Kabila cabinet.
newsitem.headline: Kinshasa residents react to Kabila cabinet.

text.p: The people of Kinshasa crowded around newspaper kiosks early on Friday, scouring reports about the absence of veteran politican Etienne Tshisekedi from a transitional government in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
Laurent Kabila, whose rebels captured the capital of the former Zaire six days ago, angered many in the city of five million by failing to appoint Tshisekedi prime minister.
"This is Kabila's first failure. Tshisekedi should be in his government," businessman Jean-Marie Tshamala told Reuters.
"We are only waiting for Tshisekedi's instruction to take to the streets," student Kambala Tshala, standing at the same newstand in the Matonge district, chipped in.
Two days behind schedule, self-proclaimed president Kabila late on Thursday announced an incomplete list of 13 cabinet ministers and dropped the position of prime minister.
He has renamed Zaire the Democratic Republic of Congo.

Senior members of his Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (ADFL) said six of the ministers were not Alliance members. But the pro-Tshisekedi La Reference newspaper said the Alliance had awarded itself all but four posts.
The Alliance said early on Friday the remaining cabinet posts would be named shortly.

The key jobs among the 13 awarded so far went to Alliance stalwarts. But the incomplete list also featured at least four non-Alliance opposition names, including two presented as Tshisekedi supporters -- Paul Bandoma and Justine Kasavubu.
Kabila's seven-month rebellion toppled the 32-year regime of President Mobutu Sese Seko, who fled Kinshasa a day before Kabila's troops marched into the capital on May 17.

Kabila was under foreign and domestic pressure to name a broad-based team before elections. For many, that meant a top job for the stubborn but courageous Tshisekedi, Mobutu's strongest civilian foe since 1990.
There was no immediate reaction on Friday from the Tshisekedi camp.
But Le Phare, one of the newspapers supporting him, headlined: "Fears for the future".
"I am always wary of those who take power by force of arms," Alain Matama, a civil servant, said in Matonge.

Le Phare's cartoonist ripped into the Alliance in a full, back-page drawing. It lampooned the Rwandan troops in the Alliance who are now ubiquitous in the capital, showing them guzzling beer in front of a nightclub.
"I'm not going back to Cyangugu," one soldier says, referring to a town in Rwanda.
